III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative
references to a youth's background or appearance
or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff use derogatory and inappropriate language towards youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported hearing staff use
curse words on occasion when interacting with youth. She
recalled an instance when Youth E called a staff member (Youth A
could not recall who) a “bitch” and she heard that staff member
call Youth E a “bitch” back to her. Youth A could not recall any
other specific instances but believed this was common. She was
unaware if Staff 6 had ever used inappropriate language towards
youth at the program.
Youth B was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled an instance when an
unknown male staff stated that he wanted to fight Youth H. Youth
B recalled this staff member stating that they “were the big dogs
here” and repeatedly stated, “Do something” to Youth H. She
could not recall if anyone else was around to witness the
exchange when this occurred. Youth B was interviewed again on
05/29/2025 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She reported an instance when Staff 9 stated to a group
of youth that included Youth H that they were “some weird ass
bitches.”
Youth C was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth C recalled several instances
when she believed that Staff 8 was laughing and taunting youth at
2

the facility. There was a time when she witnessed Youth B and
Youth G attempting to fight and as other staff tried to break it up,
Youth C saw Staff 8 laughing at the youth involved. Youth C also
commented that staff members often used swear words when
interacting with the youth, noting that this was sometimes during
escalated situations and sometimes in calm conversation.
Youth D was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported having no concerns
regarding the language used by staff towards youth at the facility.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth E stated hearing staff use
inappropriate language at times but that it was directed towards
each other, and not generally towards the youth placed at the
facility. Youth E remarked that there were times that staff
members would raise their voices and yell but it was in an attempt
to have a youth hear what they were trying to say to them.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She commented that there were a
few staff that would commonly raise their voices and use
inappropriate language towards youth, but that it generally only
occurred in response to a youth that was escalated towards
them. Youth F had no specific staff to name regarding this
concern, but did note several staff that she felt were able to stay
calm in the response to escalated youth.
Youth G was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She could not name any specific
staff members but noted that it was very common for staff to use
inappropriate language towards the youth. She remarked hearing
phrases from staff such as “Get the fuck on” when youth were
traveling to different parts of the facility, as well as staff members
state that “you kids are so fucking annoying.” She did not believe
that this was inappropriate in that it was the same kind of
language the youth used and were used to. Youth G also
commented that Staff 8 would often appear to be mocking or
laughing at youth who were escalated but could not provide any
specifics.
Youth H was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth H recalled a time when she
heard a female staff state to her “I am going to beat your ass”
during an escalated incident. Youth H could not identify any other
details or who this staff was, but did remark that she had not seen
3

the staff member working at the facility since that occurred. She
described common scenarios where staff members would be
yelling at youth, but they would be stating things such as “You
need to calm down” during escalated incidents. Youth H did not
believe the staff were any louder than the youth who was
escalated. Youth H recalled another example of staff using
inappropriate language towards youth when an unnamed female
staff remarked to another unnamed youth that she “won the fight,
good job” after an incident where staff had to break up a fight with
that youth and Youth I. Youth H could not provide any other
detailed recollections of staff member’s language towards youth.
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were interviewed separately during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 05/29/2025. They
provided consistent responses in that they denied ever using any
inappropriate or derogatory language towards youth at the facility
and did not have concern that other staff were doing the same.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not believe it was common
for staff to use inappropriate language towards youth at the
facility. Youth I remarked that an unnamed staff just the other day
had told her to “act normal.” She then recalled another instance
when an unnamed staff was on a phone call and Youth I became
upset, swearing at her. The staff member then stated “You don’t
do none of that cussing when your Mama is here” and then
returned to her phone call and stated “This bitch.” Youth I
believed that the staff member was referring to her. Youth I also
recalled witnessing a recent incident where youth were outside
and two youth attempted to fight each other. Youth I heard an
unnamed male staff state “That was a tie” regarding the youth
fighting.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that she has seen and
heard staff members using inappropriate language at the facility
towards youth. She did not have any specific staff members or
details to offer. Staff 4 noted that some of the complaints of youth
at the program were that they often did not feel respected by staff
and that this could be a contributing factor.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed a common
occurrence at the facility was that staff would fall into “power
struggles” with youth and end up using similar language back to
them that youth were using, which could often be escalated and
4

inappropriate. Staff 5 denied ever experiencing this herself and
did not have any specific examples to offer.
Staff 6 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. She
believed that it was common for other staff to use inappropriate or
threatening language towards youth. She denied ever doing so
herself and did not have any more specific details to offer.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. She could
not name any specific staff members or provide any other details,
but Staff 7 confirmed that a frequent occurrence was staff
members being verbally escalated and using inappropriate
language with youth. She felt that staff often went “back and forth”
with youth and only made an escalating situation worse.
Staff 8 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. Staff 8
denied ever mocking or insulting any youth at the facility, noting
this was the case especially when youth were escalated or coming
back to baseline from being escalated. He also denied ever
witnessing other staff use inappropriate language towards
youth. He stated hearing rumors of staff being disciplined at times
for this but did not have any specifics to share.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Employee Behavior” last revised April
2021 was provided and reviewed. This documentation
instructed staff in following manners:
o “Treat clients in a manner which supports our trauma
informed practices.”
o “Engage in communications with clients in a manner
consistent with our philosophy to be respectful,
information, connected and hope based.”
o The policy prohibited “discourteous or rude
treatment of public, clients or co-workers” and “Using
profanity or abusive language.”
• Facility policy titled “Behavior Management” last revised
December 2024 was provided and reviewed. This
documentation prohibited staff from “using profanity or
abusive language directed at or in the presence of clients.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was evidence
found that staff regularly engage with youth by using inappropriate
language.
5

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR# 2024SIC0001230 dated 05/15/2024, CAP approved 10/10/2024
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section Staff to resident ratio
Description (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility often is not able to meet ratio for the supervision of
youth as described in their policies & procedures.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that staff were often out of
ratio, knowing that the intended ratio was one staff to three
children. Youth A stated seeing one staff to five or more children
commonly on weekends.
Youth C and Youth G were interviewed separately on 05/22/2025
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. These youth
all consistently stated that they believed that there were times that
the facility was short staffed but were not able to define what that
meant or provide any other details.
Youth D was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that she was unaware
of any concerns that ratio requirements had not been met at any
given time.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that there were issues
with having enough staff for day-to-day activities at the
program. Youth E remarked that it was common that planned
activities could not occur because there were not enough staff
present. She believed this had gotten worse over time. Youth E
could not provide any other specifics.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that staff shortages were
common and often affected the day-to-day activities of the
youth. She recalled times when they would have to stay in the
unit or go watch a movie and not do activities or go outside
because there was not enough staff to supervise all of the
6

youth. Youth F also recalled that there had been several recent
instances where there was only one staff working on a unit with
eight to 10 youth at a time for short periods while other staff
arrived to work.
Youth H was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that staff were out of ratio
commonly. She noted that this might occur when she knew a
youth required one to one supervision and a staff member would
have to sit in a doorway to provide supervision to a group of youth
on one side and the youth needing one to one supervision on the
other. Youth H could not provide any other details.
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 5 were interviewed separately during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 05/29/2025. They
replied consistently to questions regarding the ratio of staff, stating
that there were times that the facility was “short-staffed” but that
did not mean that ratio was not being met. Staff would commonly
be asked to come over from the agency’s other CCI programs to
help cover ratio.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed it was common for
there not be enough staff present to meet ratio needs, causing
interruptions in the normal daily schedule. She recalled regularly
hearing staff discussing how other staff from other CCI programs
on campus were needed to come assist and that could not always
occur. An example she referred to was that there was a recent
activity where the youth were going to go to the on-site kitchen
building and do some baking but could not do so because there
was not enough staff. Youth I recalled the staff members stating
that they could stay in the unit and watch a movie and that she
heard an unnamed female staff state “At least we have enough
people for the kids to sit around and do nothing.”
Staff 3 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed there were issues
with having enough staff to meet ratio on a consistent basis. She
quoted the program’s design of having one staff to three children
to meet supervision needs. Staff 3 recalled recent instances
where there were two staff to more than seven or eight children at
a time, but could not recall any specific instances. She did note
that she has never witnessed a situation where something unsafe
happened and it was a result of the lack of supervision of the
youth.
7

Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that her role as a
clinician can technically count as part of the necessary ratio when
interacting with youth, she generally does not because she is in
and out of the units during the day. She believed that not having
enough staff to meet ratio was a common problem and referred to
the morning shift on the date of this interview as an example. She
also witnessed four youth being supervised by one staff in one of
the units the day prior.
Documentation reviewed:
• The facility “Program Statement” last revised November
2023 was provided and reviewed. This documentation
detailed the intended direct care staff ratio as one staff to
three youth during waking hours and one staff to ten youth
during sleeping hours.
• Facility timekeeping records for the months of April and
May were provided and reviewed. These records showed
consistent presence of enough staff to meet ratio of youth
placed on any given date, but they did not provide further
detail on staff assignments to specific units or youth during
those shifts. These records did not account for staff being
late or being pulled away elsewhere on campus.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance despite records showing
the facility was in ratio the interviews conducted found that the
facility has not always been able to meet the ratio standards
during daytime hours as indicated in their program statement.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are often on their personal cell phones while supervising
youth.
8

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled seeing staff move
away from supervising youth to make phone calls but could not
specify who this was. She recalled seeing these staff hide behind
doors to try not to be seen. Youth A also recalled commonly
seeing staff on their cell phones when youth were watching
movies. She did state that she had never felt like youth were
improperly supervised as a result of a staff member using their cell
phone.
Youth B was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled seeing staff members
have their phones in their possession “all the time.” Youth B
noted that there was a staff member, Staff 7, who had been
working when pregnant and Youth B often saw her with her cell
phone. Youth B felt that this was necessary because of Staff 7’s
pregnancy. She was aware that staff members had lockers
outside of the floor of the units where they were supposed to store
their cell phones before coming in to work with the youth. Youth B
felt that there were times that staff members missed what was
occurring because they were looking at their phones but was not
able to cite any specific instances.
Youth C was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled seeing staff regularly
have their phones on their person while at on the job and noted
that she was aware that this was a policy change for them at
some point.
Youth D was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated not seeing staff on their
personal cell phones.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled seeing staff members
appearing to be distracted while being with and supervising youth
because they had their personal cell phones with them but could
not provide any specifics.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported seeing staff
commonly and recently having their phones on their
person. Youth F felt that staff often tried to hide the use of their
personal cell phones, going behind doorways and looking at their
phones near their pockets while youth were watching
9

television. Youth F recalled another time when a female staff that
she could not name was on a video phone call with another
individual when a “clear” was called, and this staff member
remarked negatively to having to end the phone call.
Youth G was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed that staff members
were consistently on their phones while supervising youth. Youth
G believed that some staff would stand with their backs to security
cameras specifically so that they could not be seen with their
phone in their possession. Youth G also recalled times when staff
members would show youth things such as social media feeds on
their personal phones, as well as take personal phone
calls. Youth G could not recall any specific staff members that did
this.
Youth H was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed it was a common
occurrence that staff members would have their personal cell
phones in their hands and would be texting or calling while with
the youth. She remarked seeing a staff member do that the day of
this interview but could not confirm who the staff member was.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported that it was common
for staff members to have their personal cell phones on them
while at work when it had been made clear that the facility’s policy
stated that could not occur.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He did not have concern that staff
members had their phones with them while supervising youth. He
knew that staff were supposed to leave their cell phones in lockers
prior to coming onto the floor with youth. Prior to the interview
Staff 2 was seen interacting with youth on the floor and during the
interview his personal cell phone rang, and he took it out of his
pocket to silence it.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. While discussing the language that
staff commonly use when interacting with youth, Youth I recalled a
recent instance when a staff member was on a phone call on their
personal phone when Youth I interrupted them.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated not having an issue
10

with being able to keep her phone put away while supervising
youth but has seen other staff members not following this policy.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled witnessing a specific
recent instance when an unnamed female staff was on a video
phone call with another individual around a youth.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that there were times
that she had her personal cell phone with her while supervising
youth, and she stated being aware of the facility policy regarding
personal phones. Staff 5 stated that the walkie talkies provided to
staff for communication did not always work well and that she felt
more comfortable having her phone on her knowing that others
did as well and she could text or call someone if completely
necessary.
Youth J interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced, face-to-
face visit to the facility. At the time of the interview Youth J had
been moved to one of the other CCI programs within the agency
that was located elsewhere on campus. She referred to her time
at the facility subject to this investigation and stated that she saw
staff members with their cell phones on their person almost every
day.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. She
stated seeing other staff with their phones and using them for
activities such as looking at social media while supervising
youth. Staff 7 could not provide any specific details. She also
noted that necessary communication between staff for the day-to-
day programming and activities caused staff members to use their
own phones as opposed to other facility approved methods.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Employee Behavior” last revised April
2021 was provided and reviewed. This documentation
instructed staff in the following manners:
o “Personal cell phone use is only permitted during
scheduled breaks and are not allowed while in the
presence of clients in any residential program.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth and staff
interviews. Evidence was found that staff had their personal cell
phones with them and used them in various forms while
supervising youth.
11

CONSULTATION:
Consultation was offered regarding facility policy regarding
communication procedures among staff and personal cell phone
policy to ensure reliable and consistent communication between
staff.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR # 2024SIC0001298 dated 05/15/2024, CAP approved 10/17/2024
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Description prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints
(5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth's behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition,
medical condition, psychiatric condition, and personal
history, including any history of trauma, and must be done
in a manner consistent with the youth's treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff do not perform restraints properly.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled being restrained on
two occasions and felt that both times were justified and
performed safely. She did recall another time witnessing Youth B
being restrained and the staff members had twisted her arms
behind her. Youth A could not recall which staff members were
involved.
Youth B was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled instances when Staff
8 would hold wrists so tight when performing a restraint that his
fingernails would dig into her skin. She could not recall many
more specifics of this restraint, only noting that there were two
male staff that held her arms behind her and in doing so Staff 8
was grabbing her wrists harder than necessary because she was
not fighting back. She did not express any concerns of any other
staff at the facility regarding restraints. Youth B was interviewed
again on 05/29/2025 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She reported a recent incident where she had to be
12

restrained and she had her wrists bent back to the point of
experiencing pain by Staff 8. She recalled Staff 5 and Staff 7
being involved as well.
Youth C was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled being restrained one
time and could not recall who this was performed by. Youth C
described this restraint as occurring while she was standing up,
with two staff members holding her arms behind her. Youth C
recalled dropping her weight to the ground and in response the
staff members released her, and she was not touched by them
afterwards.
Youth D was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She remarked never seeing any
youth be restrained while placed at the facility.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated witnessing restraints
performed and felt that staff were well trained and knew how to
perform them safely. Youth E described a common restraint hold
that included the youth standing and two staff members standing
at the youth’s sides holding their arms.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed that restraints were
performed only when necessary and done so in a safe
manner. She described the most common scenario as a standing
restraint where two staff held the arms of a youth. If the youth
being restrained were to go to the ground the staff members
would let go and disengage.
Youth G was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not have any concerns to
present regarding restraints at the facility.
Youth H was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled witnessing an
instance where an unnamed male staff was restraining Youth I
and was bending her wrist backward in a manner that hurt Youth
I. She could not provide any other details and was unsure of any
other restraints she had witnessed.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not express any concerns
regarding the implementation of restraints at the facility.
13

Staff 5 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled a recent restraint
incident where she believed another staff was too aggressive and
did not use their training. Youth B was escalated and Staff 5 felt
that the restraint attempt performed on her was warranted. Staff 8
initiated the restraint attempt and in doing so he was standing with
Youth B standing as well and holding her wrist behind her. Staff 5
witnessed Staff 8 bending Youth B’s wrist back and it appeared to
her that he was doing so as a means of controlling Youth B
physically. Staff 5 believed that it was evident this was not the
correct manner of attempting the restraint because Youth B
quickly stopped fighting back and was expressing being in
pain. When Staff 8 released Youth B’s wrist, Youth B fell to the
ground and Staff 5 attempted to help her back up. Staff 5 also
noted that at the beginning of the restraint attempt Staff 8 had
ahold of Staff 5’s hair on accident, and she believed that he was
intending to grab the hair of Youth B. Staff 5 stated that she left
the situation as a result of feeling uncomfortable with how Staff 8
performed the restraint.
Staff 7 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. She
recalled an instance when Youth B had to be restrained and Staff
7 felt that Staff 8 was too aggressive in how he attempted to
perform the restraint. Staff 7 could not recall when this occurred
or who else was involved. She did recall that Youth B was
screaming that she was in pain because of the way that Staff 8
was holding her wrist behind her back. Staff 7 recalled Staff 8 not
releasing Youth B even though Youth B was not fighting back and
was clearly in pain until Staff 5 came to the situation.
Staff 8 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. He
recalled the incident in question where Youth B had to be
restrained. Staff 8 denied using excessive force when holding
Youth B’s wrists during the restraint. He believed that Youth B did
not make any mention of her wrists hurting during the
restraint. Staff 8 stated he left the situation at the end of the
restraint and was not aware of anything Youth B said at that
time. Staff 8 described his strategy for using his hands during
restraints in that he tried to only use his fingers and not his full
hand because he knew he was bigger and stronger than other
staff and did not want to risk hurting youth.
Video reviewed:
Security camera footage from within one of the units of the facility
dated 05/27/2025 was provided and reviewed. No audio
14

recording was available with the footage. At 5:18:59 PM Youth B
could be seen speaking with Staff 5. Youth B began to verbally
and physically escalate. At 5:20:40 PM Youth B bends down to
the floor and picks up an item, and Staff 5 attempts to retrieve that
item from Youth B. Youth B then began to move across the unit
towards the main door that exits the unit. As she did this a flip flop
shoe could be seen in her right hand. Staff 5 was seen holding
Youth B by the waist attempting to prevent her from moving
forward. At 5:20:48 PM the video footage skipped forward to
5:20:57 PM. At that point Youth B and Staff 5 could not be seen
near the exit door of the unit. The fish eye lens of the security
camera of the unit and dim lighting at that location did not allow for
a clear view of what was occurring next. At 5:21:14 PM the
footage skipped forward again to 5:21:20 PM. At that time Staff 8
could be seen walking to the exterior unit door location within the
unit. At 5:25:10 PM Youth B could be seen walking back into view
within the unit and entered the bedroom with the door open. This
concluded the video footage of the incident.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Behavior Management” last revised
December 2024 was provided and reviewed. This
documentation instructed staff in following manners:
o Staff were required to have training and knowledge
allowing them “the safe use of physical intervention,
including the ability to recognize and respond to
signs of physical distress in clients who are in
physical intervention or are being placed in physical
intervention.”
o “Two or more employees must be present before
physical interventions are performed.”
• Training materials in the facility’s approved restraint model,
Nonviolent Crisis Intervention, were provided and
reviewed. As a part of the most recently approved
Restraint Model Request by DCWL through the facility’s
2024 renewal inspection, the following holds were trained
for staff:
o Low, medium and high level holds in a seated
position that all involve two staff.
o Low level standing hold that involved one staff
standing to the side of a youth holding the youth’s
arms near their elbows.
o Medium level standing hold that involved two staff
standing on either side of a youth holding the youth’s
arms with their outside hands and using their inside
15

hands to brace in between the youth’s arms and
their body.
o High level standing hold that involved two staff
standing on either side of a youth holding the youth’s
wrists with their closest hand and bracing against the
youth’s hand with the staff’s other hand.
• Facility Incident Report documentation dated 05/27/2025
and authored by Staff 8 was provided and reviewed. This
detailed the incident described in interviews where Youth B
was physically restrained after becoming verbally and
physically aggressive towards staff. After Youth B
physically assaulted Staff 5, Staff 8 arrived and was able to
attempt a high level standing hold with Staff 5. This
documentation detailed Youth B continuing to fight against
the restraint until she was able to de-escalate. The incident
report does not contain any narrative stating Youth A
expressing pain in her wrists from Staff 8’s hold.
• Personnel file documentation for the following staff was
collected:
o Staff 5 was last trained in the restraint model on
06/30/2025. No discipline was noted in her file.
o Staff 8 was last trained in the restraint model on
06/30/2025. He had three instances of discipline in
his file, two for employee behavior violations.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance through youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. Evidence was found that
staff have used excessive force and non-approved restraint
methods while attempting to physically intervene with escalated
youth.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was provided in the area of facility policy &
procedure and training for behavior management and the handling
of escalated youth. Youth that are targeting or feeling triggered by
specific staff should be met with strategy to remove that staff from
the situation when it can be afforded, and this could be covered in
procedure and training further.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was provided regarding the best way for security
cameras to be installed and implemented in order to provide full
views of locations within the facility and avoid dark and blind
spots.
Conclusion Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care,
and other staff on duty to perform the prescribed
functions required by these administrative rules and in the
agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff allow youth to fight each other without attempting to properly
intervene.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled a specific instance
where youth were fighting in the gym and Youth A questioned
whether staff members had attempted to break it up timely. Youth
A remembered two youth attempting to fight Youth B while they
were in the gym. Youth A recalled seeing Staff 6 attempt to get in
the way of the youth to try to stop the fight but stated that there
were other staff members present that she felt could have acted
just as quickly. Youth A could not recall any other details of the
incident. She expressed that staff generally were present and
attempted to stop youth from fighting on a regular basis.
Youth B was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled a specific instance
where she felt that staff did not intervene properly when two other
youth that she would not name attempted to fight her in the
facility’s gymnasium. She could recall at least one staff, then
maybe another, that attempted to break up the fight but struggled
to do so. Youth B could not recall who these staff were. Youth B
clarified that staff were present and attempted to stop the fight as
well as she believed they could. Youth B could not provide any
other specifics about this incident that she could recall.
Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, and Youth G were
interviewed separately on 05/22/2025 during an announced, face-
to-face visit to the facility. These youth all independently did not
express any concerns regarding staff members being present,
engaged and able to intervene with youth when necessary.
17

Staff 1 and Staff 5 were interviewed separately during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 05/29/2025. They
reported consistent responses in that none had concern that there
had been physically escalated incidents between youth where
staff were not present or did not engage properly to attempt to
help de-escalate the situation.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He remarked that he has seen
staff members be tentative and not sure how to best intercede in
an escalated situation, and as a senior direct care staff he felt
responsible to support and help train those staff members. Staff 2
clarified that he had never witnessed a situation where
involvement by staff that would be required to de-escalate a
situation did not occur at all.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not have any concerns
with her own ability or any other staff’s ability to intervene in
escalated situations in a timely manner and could not think of any
incidents as examples of this occurring.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed that staff members
always attempted to intervene properly when there were safety
concerns with the youth at the facility.
Staff 6 was interviewed over the phone on 08/11/2025. She
recalled the incident in question where Youth B was attacked by
two other youth while in the gymnasium. Staff 6 recalled being
present the entire time and was able to attempt to intervene as
soon as the fighting occurred. She believed that other staff
members could have come to her aid but the situation did not
involve a lack of staff intervention.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Behavior Management” last revised
December 2024 was provided and reviewed. This

o “Staff must use the least restrictive, safest, and most

safety of the youth and staff in the environment.”
o Physical intervention hands-on management

a danger to self or others.
18

• A sample of Facility Incident Report documentation
involving fights between youth and restraints of youth were
provided regarding Youth B, Youth C, Youth G, and Youth
J were provided and reviewed. None of the documentation

found that staff were present and attempted to intervene in unsafe

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section Youth nutrition
Description (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible
meals daily unless medically contraindicated and
documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are fed uncooked and not safe to eat food.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D were all interviewed
separately on 05/22/2025 during an announced, face-to-face visit
to the facility. All of the youth reported similar opinions of the food
served to them at the facility, stating consistently that the food was
never raw or unsafe to eat. No youth reported ever having
concern that staff spit in their food. They all reported similar
opinions that the food was not always appetizing and that staff
would sometimes order takeout such as pizza instead of serving
what was offered for dinner. All of the youth reported that no other
internal alternatives were offered for meals unless a youth had a
specific necessary diet.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She described the food served to
the youth as “disgusting.” She believed this was the case
because the portion sizes were too small, no alternatives were
offered and the youth were served meals in repeated fashion so
there was little variety. Youth E remarked never seeing any meat
that was uncooked or raw and never seeing any expired
19

foods. She had no concerns regarding any staff spitting in youth’s
food.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She remarked that the food at the
facility was not very good and a big issue was that there were no
alternatives offered to youth. Youth F stated the common meal
schedule was three meals per day and multiple times per day
when snacks were offered. Youth F recalled a common
occurrence was milk being offered with every meal, but some of
the milk cartons offered to youth would be spoiled. Youth F stated
staff would always throw away the spoiled milk when it was
pointed out and youth would get a replacement. She had no
concerns about any staff spitting in the youth’s food.
Youth G was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth G stated a common
occurrence was milk cartons that were past their expiration dates
being offered to youth. She remarked that the youth were never
forced to consume expired items and they would be thrown away
and replaced. Youth G expressed concerns that meals would
often arrive to the unit from the kitchen that is located on campus
and they were inedible because they were now cold. Staff would
then reheat the food in the small kitchenette located in the
facility. Youth G did not have concern over uncooked food or staff
spitting in their food. Youth G would often hear staff remark that
no alternatives were available for meals and that “this is what
Vista serves.”
Youth I was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that there were occasions
when chicken was not cooked well enough when provided to them
for dinner. Youth I commented that it was common for staff to
take the meals provided and heat them further in the kitchenette in
the units when they arrived from the kitchen located elsewhere on
campus. Youth I reported staff would sometimes order pizza if
enough youth did not want to eat a meal but also noted that other
alternatives were not available within the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed that youth were
provide adequate and safe to eat meals at the facility. She
described how food was provided, that it was prepared in a
separate building on the campus that contained a large kitchen
and meals were brought to each individual building and units
throughout the day. Staff 1 confirmed that youth often did not like
20

the food provided but never saw it as unsafe to eat. She reported
never seeing expired milk that would be served to youth and
commented that staff would often go through the refrigerator
where that was stored to ensure expiration dates had not passed.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled calling the on-site
kitchen on occasion to get more food for second portions for
youth, but he did not believe this was occurring because overall
there was not enough food served on a consistent basis. Staff 2
stated taking it upon himself to heat up menu items like baked
chicken and meatloaf once it came to the units because he
wanted to make sure it was as appetizing and warmed as could
be. Staff 2 has witnessed youth refuse to eat what is served
regularly. He also noted that there were times that milk in the unit
refrigerators might pass expiration dates but it was always thrown
out and not served to the youth.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She believed that the food served
contained too little portions. She confirmed that youth were
offered snacks several times a day outside of regular
meals. Youth I recalled times when milk that was available was
expired but stated that staff never forced youth to consume it
instead offered fresh milk or water.
Staff 3 and Staff 5 were interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. They independently
stated that the food served to the youth was not always appealing
and did not eat it, but had never witnessed a situation where the
food was unsafe to eat.
Facility Tour:
• The facility was toured during an unannounced, face-to-
face visit on 05/21/2025 and on 05/29/2025. During both
visits meals served were viewed. No concerns regarding
the proper cooking or portion sizes were noted. The
kitchenette in the units was viewed and they contained milk
that was not spoiled.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Client Food Service” last dated
February 2009 was provided and reviewed. This policy
stated that the facility's “Food Services Department will
meet the daily dietary needs of our clients as established
21

by the National Dietary Association.” Appropriate serving
guidelines are outlined in this policy as well.
• The facility policy referenced above also details a process
for youth to provide feedback on food at the facility on a
“Food Service Comment” form. Email documentation from
08/13/2025 confirmed that the facility had no grievances or
Food Service Comment forms filed regarding the food
served at the facility.
• A sample of facility meal menus from March through April
2025 were provided and reviewed. These showed
adequate variety and healthy food option served to youth.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was evidence
found that youth are served adequate and safe to eat meals at the
facility.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was provided to address procedures within
units to ensure that no expired or spoiled food or drink is provided
to youth at mealtimes.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was provided regarding the opportunity for the facility
to better offer alternative meal options to youth. Consultation was
also offered regarding the facility’s use of federal school lunch
programming and how to attempt to provide information on it to
youth. In addition, consultation was offered in the area of having
the kitchen staff examine menus and cooking methods to provide
the most appealing food possible to youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section Facility and premises maintenance
Description (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be
located on land that is properly drained.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility is in a consistent state of disrepair, creating an unsafe
living environment.
22

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth G, and Youth I
were all interviewed separately on 05/22/2025 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. They reported similar
concerns, noting that it was common for windows to be broken
and broken glass to be within reach after an incident
occurred. The youth did all consistently state that maintenance
staff would quickly board up windows and clean up unsafe debris
from incidents.
Youth E was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She expressed concerns about the
physical state of the building, stating there were almost always
broken windows in some state of repair or being cleaned
up. Youth A also commented that walls would have holes in them
from youth kicking or punching them. Youth A reported that some
furniture had to be taken out of the units because youth were able
to climb on top and attempt to grab hold of the ceiling, including
the desks that staff used within the units.
Youth F was interviewed on 05/22/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She recalled a specific instance
when Youth B broke a window while escalated and was able to
get ahold of glass shards before staff were able to clean it up.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She reported common
occurrences where escalated youth would damage property such
as walls, furniture and windows when escalated. She believed it
was difficult to ensure that no one had access to dangerous debris
when this occurred but also stated that maintenance staff were
fast in the repair of any of these issues.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He did not have concern that there
were unsafe living conditions at the facility as a result of damage
done to property by youth. Staff 2 believed that maintenance staff
acted quickly to ensure that unsafe living situations were made
safer.
Youth I was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She knew that there was at least
one broken window or wall at any given time. Youth I commented
that staff and maintenance crew would clean up after property
damage in a timely manner. Despite this, Youth I recalled finding
23

small shards of glass on the floor on occasion and telling staff
about it.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She did not believe the common
broken windows or damaged walls were safety issues for the
youth because staff cleaned up debris quickly and maintenance
staff acted quickly on repairing anything damaged.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/29/2025 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She commonly witnessed broken
windows and other damaged property at the facility and noted that
staff are quick to attempt to clean and make a situation safe but
that sometimes youth themselves are faster at cleaning up things
like broken windows.
Facility Tour:
• The facility was toured during an unannounced, face-to-
face visit on 05/21/2025 and on 05/29/2025. On both
occasions there were numerous broken interior and exterior
windows, damaged walls and furniture and removed items
such as desks within the units because of damage and
safety concerns. The broken windows were boarded up in a
temporary manner with particle board. There were several
doors that would not close easily or properly because of
damage inflicted by youth. Units contained large opened
trash bags on the floor collecting items for youth or being
used for throwing away refuse. Some youth bedrooms had
broken blinds covering the windows.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility maintenance logs for the months of April and May
2025 were provided and reviewed. This documentation
showed frequent work requests of the maintenance staff
involving repairing or replacing broken items and boarding

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth and staff
interviewed, documentation reviewed, and facility tour. Evidence
was found that Beata Hall was not kept in safe condition. The
population in the program are youth with a variety of mental health
issues and psychiatric needs.
Conclusion Violation Established
